question: The abnormal fiber that is seen with Gomori trichrome staining is typical of: <image 1>
description:
The image shows a muscle biopsy stained with Gomori trichrome stain. The majority of the muscle fibers appear light blue, which is characteristic of normal muscle tissue under this staining method. However, there is one prominent muscle fiber that stands out due to its abnormal appearance. This particular fiber has a dark red or purple coloration, indicating an abnormality in its composition. The darkly stained area appears granular and is concentrated within the fiber, suggesting the presence of abnormal material or structures. The surrounding muscle fibers maintain their typical light blue color, indicating they are relatively unaffected by whatever process is causing the abnormality in the single fiber. 

This type of staining pattern, where a single muscle fiber appears abnormally dark red or purple, is indicative of a mitochondrial disorder. In such disorders, the mitochondria within the muscle cells accumulate abnormally, leading to the intense staining observed. This accumulation disrupts the normal function of the muscle fibers, resulting in the characteristic dark staining seen in the image. Therefore, the abnormal fiber seen in the image is typical of a mitochondrial disorder.
